SUMMARY In Pakistan, custody rules are determined by the personal status laws of the persons
involved. For Muslims, the courts rely on uncodified Islamic law to determine the
physical custody and guardianship of a child, subject to the paramount consideration
of the welfare of the child. Under Islamic law, the father is considered a child’s natural
guardian. However, under the rules of hizanat, or a mother’s right to physical custody
as established by Hanafi Muslim personal law, a mother has this right over her male
child until the age of seven and over her female child until the child reaches puberty. It
should be noted that the courts in Pakistan have at times deviated from Hanafi
jurisprudential rules when it is in the best interest of the child.

Although there are many Pakistani court decisions on the recognition of foreign custody
court orders and judgments (the “principle of comity of courts”), we were unable to
find any concerning whether foreign custody law or domestic law is applied in cases
where foreign Afghan citizens are resident in Pakistan. Most of the cases involve
parents abducting a child or custody disputes involving Pakistani and foreign or dual
citizenship nationals.

I. Introduction and Jurisdictional Issues

In Pakistan, custody rules are determined by the personal status laws of the persons involved. If
the persons concerned are Muslims, then under section 2 of the West Pakistan Muslim Personal
Law (Shariat) Application Act 1962, Muslim personal law is applicable.

Court orders for custody and guardianship in Pakistan are made according to the Guardians and

having jurisdiction in the place where the minor ordinarily resides.” However, it appears that
the West Pakistan Family Courts Act, 1964,4 has overriding application on the issue of territorial
jurisdiction. It states, “A Family Court shall be deemed to be a District Court for the purposes of
the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890 and notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, shall, in

B. Custody and Best Interest of the Child

In 1987, the Supreme Court of Pakistan in Mst. Feroze Begum v. Lt. Col. Muhammad Hussain
established the “principle that the paramount and overriding consideration in the custody cases”
is the welfare of the minor.

[t]he overriding and paramount consideration always is the welfare of the minor. Indeed
this is the sole consideration that must prevail in the final analysis and the fact that the
father is the lawful guardian of his minor children does not compel the Court to pass an
order in his favour unless it is in their welfare to do so.

The welfare of a minor means his material, intellectual, moral and spiritual well-being.

It should be noted that Pakistani courts have deviated from classical Hanafi jurisprudence and
“have based their judgments on the “Best Interests of the Child’ principle.” 5 The authors of an
article on cross-border child abduction note that, regarding Pakistan, “A brief discussion of recent
case law suggests that while historical Islamic legal rulings on hidana inform the judicial
determination of a child’s welfare, those rules are not determinative and can be overridden when
the welfare of the child requires another custodial arrangement.” '¢

has been construed by the Courts in Pakistan that this may not be an absolute rule but it
may be departed from, if there are exceptional circumstances to justify such departure and
in making of such departure the only fact, which the Court has to see where the welfare of
minor lies and there may be a situation where despite second marriage of the mother, the
welfare of minor may still lie in her custody.'®

Section 17 of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890, enshrines the principle of the best interest of
the child, which Pakistani courts have made their paramount consideration in issuing custody
and guardianship orders. Section 17 stipulates as follows:

17. Matters to be considered by the Court in appointing guardian. (1) In appointing
or declaring the guardian of a minor, the Court shall, subject to the provisions of this
section, be guided by what, consistently with the law to which the minor is subject, appears
in the circumstances to be for the welfare of the minor.

(2) In considering what will be for the welfare of the minor, the Court shall have
regard to the age, sex and religion of the minor, the character and capacity of the proposed
guardian and his nearness of kin to the minor, the wishes, if any, of a deceased parent, and
any existing or previous relations of the proposed guardian with the minor or his property.

(3) If the minor is old enough to form an intelligent preference, the Court may
consider that preference.

Currently, the courts are “following the principle of [the] welfare of [the] minor in the cases of
custody while passing orders, whether interlocutory or final.” 2°

In addition to the factors included in section 17(2) of the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890, the
courts consider the stability of the environment and the educational, emotional, and other needs
of the child.2! In “giving primacy to the child’s welfare, Pakistani law recognizes that the child
may be in the best position to determine his or her own interests.”22 According to researcher
Cassandra Balchin, while deciding petitions under the Guardians and Wards Act, 1890, “courts
have preferred a case by case consideration of the fact rather than rigidly applying the principles
of established Muslim Jurisprudence.”3

III. International Child Abduction

There is no extradition treaty between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Pakistan become a signatory of
the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, 1980, in December
2016, which entered into force in Pakistan on March 1, 2017.74 The “objects of the Convention are
to secure the prompt return of the children wrongfully removed or retained and ensure the rights
of the children.” To provide domestic effect, the convention was added to the Schedule of the
West Pakistan Family Courts Act, 1964, to “bring international child Abduction cases within the
jurisdiction of the family court in Islamabad Capital Territory (ICT) and all Provinces of Pakistan
including Azad Kashmir and Gilgit Baltistan also done [sic] the same.” For the convention to be
operational between signatory states, the older member needs to accept the accession of the new
member. Afghanistan is not a signatory of the convention, so it is not applicable between the
two countries.26

The Pakistan Penal Code (PPC) has a number of offenses relating to kidnapping and abduction,
including kidnapping from lawful guardianship.?’ Sections 359 to 374 of the PPC deal with the
crime of kidnapping and abduction. A habeas corpus petition is also used to recover custody of

Generally, a case of child abduction by a parent is perceived as a civil dispute as opposed to a
criminal offense.

The judiciary, in various cases, opined that parents could not be held responsible for the
offence of abduction of their children. The leading case on this point is Muhammad Ashraf
v SHO and others 26 in which the court held that a parent couldn’t be punished for
abducting his own child. However, there was an instance where the Federal Shariat Court
of Pakistan in Mst Asia Bibi v Alam Khan 27 maintained a view that a father was held
liable for abduction his daughter from lawful custody of her maternal uncle and maternal
grandfather. It could thus be stated that the law relating to child custody is uneven, and

courts have demonstrated favour for the opinion that a parent couldn’t be viewed an
abductor of his child.”

IV. Conflict of Laws/Private International Law

Although there are many Pakistani court decisions on the recognition of foreign custody court
orders and judgments,*? (the “principle of comity of courts”*!), we were unable to find any
concerning whether foreign custody law or domestic law is applied where foreign Afghan
citizens are resident in Pakistan. Most of the cases involve the “problem of international parental
child abduction to Pakistan along with the applicable Pakistani law in custody disputes involving
both Pakistani and foreign/dual nationals.”>2 However, an article in the periodical Dawn states,
“if the child was born in a country other than Pakistan and has been given foreign nationality,
then the court would also consider foreign law.”* According to the authors of Family Laws in
Pakistan, [iJn custody of children cases, Pakistani courts give paramount importance to the
principle of the welfare of the child. This principle is also endorsed under Private
International Law.” 34

The leading case on this point is Muhammad Ashraf  v SHO and others 26 in which the court held that a parent couldn’t be punished for  abducting his own child. However, there was an instance where the Federal Shariat Court  of Pakistan in Mst Asia Bibi v Alam Khan 27 maintained a view that a father was held  liable for abduction his daughter from lawful custody of her maternal uncle and maternal  grandfather. It could thus be stated that the law relating to child custody is uneven, and  courts have demonstrated favour for the opinion that a parent couldn’t be viewed an  abductor of his child.   
IV.  Conflict of Laws/Private International Law   
Although there are many Pakistani court decisions on the recognition of foreign custody court  orders and judgments,  (the “principle of comity of courts” 31 ), we were unable to find any  concerning whether foreign custody law or domestic law is applied where foreign Afghan  citizens are resident in Pakistan. Most of the cases involve the “problem of international parental  child abduction to Pakistan along with the applicable Pakistani law in custody disputes involving  both Pakistani and foreign/dual nationals.” 32  However, an article in the periodical Dawn states,  “if the child was born in a country other than Pakistan and has been given foreign nationality,  then the court would also consider foreign law.” 33  According to the authors of  Family Laws in  Pakistan , [i]n custody of children cases, Pakistani courts give paramount importance to the  principle of the welfare of the child. This principle is also endorsed under Private  International Law.” 34
